titleStmt.title: Gotha, Forschungsbibliothek Gotha, Ms. orient. A 443

respStmt.resp: Edited by Michael Marx in collaboration with Tobias J. Jocham et. al. TEI version created by Yasmin Faghihi and Huw Jones

availability.p: Image credits: Johann Heinrich Moeller, Paläographische Beiträge aus den Herzoglichen Sammlungen in Gotha: Orientalische Paläographie, Eisleben 1844, Tafel VI.

summary.p: 2 fol. on parchment; Shelfmark: Ms. orient. A 443; Qurʾānic Text: Q 10:93-11:9, Q 12:44-12:70; 18 lines per page; Dimensions: 320 x 255mm; Script style: kūfī B.I.b; Estimated date of production: 700-800 AD.

A 443 and the manuscript Arabe 325 (a) from the Bibliothèque national de France originally belonged to the same Qurʾān codex. The script is very close to the script of the manuscripts: Paris Arabe 333 (b) from the Bibliothèque national de France and Doḥa HC.MS.03190 from the Qatar National Library collection, alongside with other four sister fragments.
The catalogue of Arabic manuscripts written by Wilhelm Pertsch gives the following information (Pertsch 1878, III:1, p. 384f.):

"443. (Möll. 1b, Nr. 13.) Zwei Blätter Pergament, 25,5 auf 32 cm, die Seite zu 18 Zeilen. Fol.1 enthält Sûr. X, 93 بنى اسرآئل bis IX, 12 منّا, Fol. 2 Sûr. XII, 44 Anfang bis 70 جعل ا[لسقاية; Fol. 2b ist facsimilirt bei Möller a. a. O., Taf. VI, Nr. 2. – Die Schrift ist ein kleines Kûfisch, welches dem Naschî schon ziemlich nahe steht. Die diakritischen Zeichen sind vollständig vorhanden, zum Theil als Striche zum Theil als Punkte. Vocalisation die gewöhnliche; grüne Punkte bezeichnen den betreffenden Vocal mit Hamz. Verstheilung zwei schief gelagerte schwarze Striche; Pentadentheiler ein aufrecht stehender, dicker, schwarz umzogener rother Strich, Dekadentheiler ein grosser, schwarz verzierter rother Punkt (also ähnlich wie in Cod. 433 u. 455). Dehnungs-Alif fehlt; zur Ausfüllung der Zeile ist am Ende derselben nicht selten ein kleiner horizontaler Strich beigefügt. – Aus Fol. 1b, wo Sûr. X schliesst und XI beginnt, sehen wir, dass die Handschrift den Sûren keine Überschriften, sondern vielmehr Unterschriften zu geben pflegte; die Unterschrift der zehnten Sûrah lautet dort (roth geschrieben): هذه ختمه سوره ٮونس وهى ماٮه و تسع اٮت. "

A facsimile of fol. 2v of this manuscript was included in Johann Möller palaeographic catalogue (Möller 1844, pl. VI, No. 2) and is accessible as image no. 2.

support.p: Fol. 1r is hair side, 1v is flesh side, 2r is flesh side, 2v is hair side. Flesh side is facing hair side, according to the observations made on the sister fragment Arabe 325 (a).

Vers markers: Group of three points, similar to the diacritical marks, arranged in a triangle mark the end of a verse; the letter ʾalif in red ink, outlined with dark brown ink indicates the fifth verse; end of every tenth verse is marked with a circle in red and black. The end of a Sūrah is announced with the formula haḏihi ḫātimatu sūrati followed by the name of the Sūrah and the number or verses in red ink, as on the fol. 1v.

summary.p: The text is written in the early kūfī script style B.Ib, representing the transitional period between the kūfī and ḥiǧāzī. The ʾalif is strictly vertical, as well as other vertical characters of the script. The initial ʿayn has more resemblance with the style B.Ia as it rather has a rounded than an angular form as in B.Ib.

Diacritical marks are used frequently, indicated by short oblique dashes. There is another layer of diacritics made by a later hand, marking mostly the letter yāʾ with two dots. The letter fāʾ is marked with a dot above, the qāf is originally left unmarked, a later hand marks the letter with two dots above. Vocalisation is made by red dots, hamza is indicated by a green dot. Often small lines are placed at the end of a line to fill out the space.
